{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Malay titles|Yang Berbahagia Datuk]] | name = Vinod Sekhar | image = | caption = | birth_name = Vinod Balachandra Sekhar | birth_date = 6 August 1968 | birth_place = Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Malaysian | alias = | ethnicity = | height = | weight = | spouse = Datin Dr. Winy Sekhar
}}
[[Malay titles|Datuk]] '''Vinod Balachandra Sekhar''' is the President and Group Chief Executive of Petra Group, a Malaysian company that focuses on [[rubber recycling]], [[biotechnology]] and financial software.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leadership Summit Asia 2008|url=http://www.insead.edu/events/leadershipsummitasia2008/speakers/sekhar.cfm|publisher=Insead}}</ref> He is also the chairman of the Sekhar Foundation, based in [[Kuala Lumpur]] and the CEO of Green Rubber. He was named by ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine as Malaysia's 28th richest man for 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysia's Richest No. 28 Vinod Sekhar|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/84/malaysia-09_Vinod-Sekhar_TL7H.html|work=Forbes.com|accessdate=27 May 2009}}</ref>Nevertheless, there were complaints filed against him, leading to lawsuits.
The title of Dato' was given to Sekhar at the early age of 26 by [[Yang di Pertuan Besar]] of Negeri Sembilan, Tuanku Ja'afar Ibni Almarhum Tuanku Abdul Rahman on his 71st birthday, who was at that time the 10th Yang di Pertuan Agong of Malaysia. He was the youngest person to be conferred a Dato'ship.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cinderella Man|url=http://themalaysiamovement.com/images/Cinderella_Man.pdf}}</ref>
==Personal and Family Life== Sekhar is the youngest son of Sukumari Nair and [[B.C. Sekhar]], also known as Mr. Natural Rubber, who for a time provided significant inputs in the global [[natural rubber]] industry. He has three siblings. He is married to Winy Sekhar with whom he has two daughters, Petra and Tara.<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysian Rubber Industry Pioneer B.C. Sekhar Dies|url=http://news.oneindia.in/2006/09/07/malaysian-rubber-industry-pioneer-b-c-sekhar-dies-1157610620.html|publisher=One India News|accessdate=7 September 2006}}</ref>
Aside from managing his businesses, Sekhar takes time to write literary contents. He has written numerous plays and even produced a book of poetry. "In the Mind's Eye", one of the plays that he has written was a success and was well received when it was produced in the United States, United Kingdom and in his homeland, [[Malaysia]]. Dato Vinod paid for it to be produced.
Moreover, he became the host of the first English talk show on television in Malaysia.
He also enjoys playing golf with a 22 handicap.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roop|first=Sharma|title=Vinod Sekhar : Malaysia's most prominent businessmen, philanthropists|url=http://www.nriinternet.com/NRIentrepreneurs/ASIA/Malaysia/A_Z/Vinod_Sekhar/Forbes_Malaysia_40richest_2007%20.htm|publisher=NRI Internet|accessdate=30 May 2007}}</ref>
==Career life== While he attended [[Haileybury and Imperial Service College]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysian work experience offer for six pupils|url=http://haileybury.com/news/archive/Default.asp?id=266&offset=400|publisher=Haileybury and Imperial Service College|accessdate=15 August 2010}}</ref> and writes broadly – for instance<ref>"Malaysia in the Asian Century: The Challenges we all face", in: [[Frank-Jürgen Richter]] and Thang D. Nguyen: ''The Malaysian Journey'', Marshall Cavendish 2004.</ref> he started a non-partisan multiracial youth organisation, Malaysiana Muda. He remained president of one of the largest multiracial youth organisations in Malaysia at that time for two terms.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vinod Sekhar|url=http://greenleaderssummit.com/vinod-sekhar|publisher=Green Leaders Summit}}</ref>
Sekhar was only 21 when he started his business career with just US$50 when he put up his own clothing company called Vincent Siefer Clothing Company that sold college embossed shirts to university students in different American universities. He later then sold his clothing company for US$5 million.{{cn|date=April 2016}}
In 1990, Sekhar formed Sekhar Tunku Imran (STI) Group together with his friend, Tunku Tan Sri Imran and penetrated various business ventures. Some of the most notable business deals that STI had was when it had a joint venture with [[Disney-MGM Studios]] in Florida, USA to produce the movie entitled Tarzan, The Epic Adventure.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roop|first=Sharma|title=Vinod Sekhar : Malaysia's most prominent businessmen, philanthropists|url=http://www.nriinternet.com/NRIentrepreneurs/ASIA/Malaysia/A_Z/Vinod_Sekhar/Forbes_Malaysia_40richest_2007%20.htm|publisher=NRI Internet|accessdate=30 May 2007}}</ref>
Over the years, STI teamed up with various business partners both in the local and international scene that in 1997, the Petra Group was born.
The Petra Group is a privately held company that is well known for Green Rubber Global – the company's key business which is a cost-effective process that can efficiently recycle used rubber.
Sekhar is also an active supporter of different socio-civic organisations. He founded the Sekhar Foundation which owns 60% of The Petra Group and acts as the philanthropic arm of the company by supporting various charitable organisations worldwide. The Sekhar Foundation has donated to a range of organisations that are working in the fields of education, poverty alleviation, and healthcare provision. The Foundation is also the main sponsor for South East Asia's largest rain forest research programme in the Danum Valley in [[Borneo]].<ref>http://www.insead.edu/events/leadershipsummitasia2008/speakers/sekhar.cfm</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=University Council Members: Dato Vinod Sekhar|url=http://www.limkokwing.net/university_guidance/council/datuk_vinod_sekhar/|publisher=Limkokwing University of Creative Technology}}</ref>
=== Green Rubber Global ===
Green Rubber Global (GRG) is a part of Sekhar's Petra Group. A recycling plant is being built near Gallup, New Mexico in USA to pave way to Green Rubber production. Aside from that, GRG is planning to expand and build more recycling plants in US, [[Mexico]] and Asia to increase production.<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysian rubber recycler expands into USA|url=http://www.recyclinginternational.com/recycling-news/5170/other-news/archiv/malaysian-rubber-recycler-expands-usa|publisher=Recycling International|accessdate=1 October 2007}}</ref>
The recycling plant will make use of the process that Sekhar's father has developed called De-Link to create "green rubbers". The De-Link process will devulcanise old and used tyres then revulcanise them and convert them into different new rubber products such as vehicle tyres and footwear soles.<ref>{{cite web|last=Matthew|first=Phan|title=Watch 'green rubber' bounce back to life soon|url=http://www.wildsingapore.com/news/20070910/070912-5.htm|publisher=Wild Singapore|accessdate=12 September 2007}}</ref>
GRG has famous supporters and shareholders like Hollywood celebrities [[Mel Gibson]] and [[Bruce Willis]] and ''Forbes'' magazine publisher, [[Steve Forbes]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Mel Gibson-backed firm Green Rubber eyes London IPO|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/09/11/rubber-ipo-mel-gibson-idUSL1184655720070911|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=11 September 2007}}</ref> However, Bruce Willis then sued the company to recoup US$900,000 (RM3.1mil) of the US$2mil he invested.In his complaint filed in the federal court in Los Angeles, Willis said Petra chief executive officer Datuk Vinod B. Sekhar and Tunku Imran induced him to invest in this company <ref>{{cite web|title=Bruce Willis sues Petra and Tunku Imran|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2008/11/22/bruce-willis-sues-petra-and-tunku-imran|publisher=The Star Newspaper|accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref>
==Achievements, Awards and Honours==
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Recognition !! Recognition Giving Body !! Year |- | Corporate Leader of the Year || SJ Grant Thornton || 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=SJ Grant Thornton Awards its inaugural Corporate Leader of the Year|url=http://www.gt.com.my/corporate_leader_of_the_year_award.html}}</ref> |- | 16th Richest Man in Malaysia || ''Forbes'' magazine || 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=Malaysia's Richest No. 16 Vinod Sekhar|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2008/84/biz_malaysiarichest08_Vinod-Sekhar_TL7H.html|work=Forbes.com|accessdate=21 May 2008}}</ref> |- | Product/Industrial Design Award || Global Green USA || 2008<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Green USA Sustainable Design Awards Honorees|url=http://www.globalgreen.org/articles/global/38}}</ref> |- | Community Leadership Award || Global Organization for People of Indian Origin (GOPIO) || 2010<ref>{{cite web|title=7 Indian-origin persons to get GOPIO award|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/seven-people-get-gopio-award/20091228.htm|publisher=Rediff News|accessdate=28 December 2009}}</ref> |}
Dato' Vinod was also one of the first Malaysians to venture into the former Soviet Union after its breakup and was a part of the privatization of its second largest petrochemical plant. He was also the first Southeast Asian to own both Formula 2000 and Formula 3 Championship motorsports teams, and he founded Malaysia’s first sports car company.<ref>http://www.vinodsekhar.net/bio.html</ref><ref>http://datukvinod.com</ref>
Dato' Vinod has presented a variety of papers at and participated in many international conferences including the International Human Rights Conference in Brussels, the first Malaysian International Youth Conference for Unity in Kuala Lumpur, the Asia Europe Young Leaders Conference in Ireland, the New Asian Leaders Retreat in Seoul, South Korea programmer for the World Economic Forum, the WEF’s Davos Annual meeting, he was the Chair of the first New Asian Leaders–Emerging Arab Leaders Summit in Langkawi, which was attended by King Abdullah II of Jordan, and he was a speaker at the 2005 Forbes Global CEO Conference in Sydney.<ref>http://www.vinodsekhar.net/bio.html</ref><ref>http://datukvinod.com</ref>
Dato' Vinod is the Chairman of the Sekhar Foundation (which he founded and which currently plays a role in the lives of over 12,000 children globally), the Chairman of the Pelita Harapan (Lantern of Hope) for terminally ill children, the Co-Chairman of the Innocent Child Appeal Fund Board for abused children, and the Chairman of the Sitavani Foundation. He was also the founding President of Malaysian Muda, the first nonpartisan multiracial national youth organization created to develop unity among Malaysian youth, where he warned of polarization among young Malaysians two decades before the government finally acknowledged it was out of control.<ref>http://www.vinodsekhar.net/bio.html</ref><ref>http://datukvinod.com</ref>
In 1991, for his contribution to the globalization of education and the education of children, Dato' Vinod was made the first and youngest Asian fellow of [[Kappa Delta Pi]], a US-based international Honors Society for Education. This organization awarded its “ The Point of Excellence ” award to his company, the first Asian company to be so honored. Dato' Vinod was 26 years old and one of the youngest to be so honored. The World Economic Forum named him as one of its 40 “New Asian Leaders” (NAL). Grant Thornton named him the Malaysian Corporate Leader of the Year in August 2008.<ref>http://www.vinodsekhar.net/bio.html</ref><ref>http://datukvinod.com</ref>
He has written several plays and a book of poetry. One of his plays, “In the Mind’s Eye,” was produced with success in the US, UK and Malaysia. Datuk Vinod also hosted Malaysia’s first English language talk show on television. He has also jointly won several New York Festival Awards for his cutting-edge advertising campaigns. In addition to playing golf, tennis and squash, he has a black belt in Judo and is an avid fan of Walt Disney and Mickey Mouse. He has over 290 Disney ties.<ref>http://www.vinodsekhar.net/bio.html</ref><ref>http://datukvinod.com</ref>
In 2013, Dato' Vinod produced the Indian Film "Liar's Dice"<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6941206/</ref> which features the story of Kamala, a young woman from Chitkul village and her girl child Manya, who embarks on a journey leaving their native land in search for her missing husband.<ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2343621/plotsummary?ref_=tt_ov_pl</ref>
Dato' Vinod Sekhar has FALSELY CLAIMED that he was awarded the Bharat Samaan Award by the NRI Institute in India.<ref>http://www.greenrubberglobal.org</ref>
==Disputes== === Declared bankruptcy in 2005 and Insolvency Dept bid against Vinod Sekhar in 2010 ===
In June 2005, the Kuala Lumpur High Court declared Sekhar a bankrupt due to failure of settling his debts to Orix Credit Malaysia Sdn Bhd and 11 other companies that totals RM 12.376 million.According to the application that the director-general of the Insolvency Department has submitted to KL's High Court, Sekhar committed two offences when he was still in directorship of 25 companies and flew out of the country without gaining permission from the Director-General of Insolvency, under Section 38 of the Bankruptcy Act 1967.However, in March 2011, Sekhar's attorney successfully proved to the court that the adjudication and receiving order documents pertaining to the bankruptcy were never served on his client and that the signatures appearing on those documents were forged. Because of that, the application to put Sekhar to jail was dismissed by High Court Senior Assistant Registrar Rozianti Mohamed Hanaphi.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vinod Sekhar won't respond to allegations company|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2010/09/04/vinod-sekhar-wont-respond-to-allegations/|publisher=The Star Newspaper|accessdate=4 September 2010}}</ref>
=== The filing of Lawsuit by Bruce Willis in 2008 ===
Hollywood actor Bruce Willis filed a lawsuit against Vinod Sekhar and Malaysian Prince Imran Ibni Tuanku Ja'afar last November 2008 when the actor wanted to get his $2 million investment but only received $1.1 million.[18]The actor sued Sekhar and Ja'afar for the remaining $900, 000 of his total investment immediately after learning that the plan to launch green rubber was put on hold because of the weakening global economy. In his complaint filed in the federal court in Los Angeles on 22 November 2008, Willis said Petra chief executive officer Datuk Vinod B. Sekhar and Tunku Imran induced him to invest in a company that was developing a non-toxic and recyclable rubber in 2007, according to a Bloomberg report. Willis was told that former US Vice-President Al Gore and actor Mel Gibson had also invested in the company. <ref>{{cite web|title=Bruce Willis sues Petra and Tunku Imran|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2008/11/22/bruce-willis-sues-petra-and-tunku-imran|publisher=The Star Newspaper|accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref> The dispute was then resolved. <ref>{{cite web|title=Bruce Willis settles dispute with Malaysia company|url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2008Nov26/0,4675,PeopleBruceWillis,00.html|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=28 November 2008}}</ref>
=== Complaints by University of St Andrews in 2010 ===
Vinod Sekkhar was involved in a dispute over a donation to the University of St Andrews in Scotland. He never kept his promise of a donation and the school was forced to seek funding elsewhere. <ref>{{cite web|title=Scottish university's £8m 'donor' faces jail |url=https://www.scotsman.com/news/scottish-university-s-163-8m-donor-faces-jail-1-1369351|publisher=The Scottman, The Scotland's National Newspaper|accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref>

'''William Leonard Carter''', [[Royal Engineers|R.E.]] (1877 – 4 July 1917) was a [[British people|British]] businessman and army officer.
He was born in [[Shanghai]] in 1877 was educated at [[St. Paul's School, London]]. He continued his studies in technical direction at the [[Central Technical College]].<ref name="Obituary">{{cite book|page=537|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=5311360|title=Obituary Notices}}</ref>
Carter served as a 2nd Lieutenant in the [[East Lancashire Regiment]] during the [[South African War]]. Later he moved to Hong Kong and joined the China and Japan Telephone Company as a local agent and manager for 13 years. He was keen on forming the Hong Kong Local Centre of the Institution and became the first Chairman of the Local Centre in 1915.<ref name="Obituary"/>
He became Adjutant of the [[Royal Hong Kong Regiment|Hong Kong Volunteer Reserves]] with the local rank of Captain during the [[First World War]]. He later resigned from the post and became the [[officer commanding]] of the [[Royal Engineers]] stores.<ref name="Obituary"/>
He died from enteric fever at the Military Hospital in Hong Kong on 4 July 1917.<ref name="Obituary"/> He was buried at the [[Hong Kong Cemetery]].

{{Orphan|date=March 2011}}
The '''Williamson trade-off model''' is a theoretical model in the [[economics]] of [[industrial organization]] which emphasizes the trade-off associated with [[horizontal merger]]s between gains resulting from lower [[marginal cost|costs of production]] and the losses associated with higher [[price]]s due to greater degree of [[monopoly power]].<ref>Robert Beynon, [https://books.google.com/books?id=26m3RXKUuQIC&pg=PA349&lpg=PA349&dq=Williamson+trade+off+model&source=bl&ots=2EzE7a9bfw&sig=B1AVpfWqnzC70fm35GJso3iNedQ&hl=en&ei=TGJNS--gM5X2NYWx2O4M&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CCkQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade%20off%20model&f=false "The Routledge critical dictionary of global economics"], Taylor & Francis, 1999, p. 349</ref>
The model was first presented by [[Oliver Williamson]] in his 1968 paper "Economies as an Antitrust Defense: The welfare tradeoffs" in the ''[[American Economic Review]]''.<ref>Williamson, Oliver, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1831653 "Economies as an Antitrust Defense: The welfare tradeoffs"], The ''American Economic Review'', Vol. 58, No. 1 (March 1968), pp. 18–36</ref> Williamson argued that ignoring efficiencies that may result from proposed mergers in antitrust law "fail[ed] to meet the basic test of economic rationality".<ref>Katalin Judit Cseres, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ov6Vr9ev57MC&pg=PT32&lpg=PT32&dq=Williamson+trade+off+model&source=bl&ots=e3EjP3DuHN&sig=2pKrldsGbpaPlwTodsQoWzSlpjo&hl=en&ei=mmVNS9ehCJT4NY2wgOoM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CB4Q6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20&f=false "Competition law and consumer protection"], Kluwer Law International, 2005, p. 139</ref>
[[Image:WilliamsonTOmodel.JPG|thumb|300px|Graphical illustration of the Williamson trade-off model]]
==Basic idea of the model==
Suppose that a given industry is initially characterized by [[perfect competition]] and has a constant unit cost of production equal to ''c1'' (assumed the same across all firms in the industry). Because of competition, the market price of the good produced will be equal to this unit cost, which means that firms in the industry earn [[normal profit]]s, as captured by the [[producer surplus]] (the area below the market price, but above the supply/unit cost curve).<ref name=AnP/>
Suppose further that after a merger between firms in the industry takes place, unit costs fall to ''c2<c1'' as a result of [[economies of scale]] or other forms of [[synergy]]. However, the industry is now less competitive, with a [[monopoly]] being the most extreme example. Since the firm is no longer a [[price-taking|price taker]], the price it charges will be above the (now lower) unit cost. For a monopoly, for example, the price will be set where the unit/marginal cost intersects [[marginal revenue]]. This means that the amount of [[consumer surplus]], the area below the demand curve and above the price, will be lower.<ref name=AnP/>
The change in overall [[social surplus]] of the market depends on whether the increase in producer surplus due to lower production costs is larger or smaller than the fall in consumer surplus due to higher prices. Note that it is theoretically possible that the fall in unit costs due to the merger could be sufficiently large that the post merger monopoly price ends up being lower than the pre merger competitive price in which case both producer and consumer surplus would increase. In that situation no trade-off exists and the merger is unambiguously beneficial to all market participants. More generally however, a horizontal merger can involve both costs and benefits.<ref name=AnP/>
==Applications in antitrust policy==
One implication of the Williamson model is that the gains from cost reduction do not have to be "large" in order to outweigh the losses that result from higher prices.<ref name=AnP/> This is because the welfare losses associated with the latter tend to be "second-order" (graphically, they are triangles), while the gains tend to be "first-order" (rectangles). What this means is that the gains from the merger would have to be very small, or alternatively, the demand for the good in question would have to be relatively quite [[Price elasticity of demand|inelastic]] for social surplus to decrease.<ref name=AnP/>
A broader conclusion of the model is that [[Competition law|antitrust]], or competition, policy should be "discretionary".<ref name=CLP>C. L. Pass, Bryan Lowes, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ffoNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA177&lpg=PA177&dq=Williamson+trade-off+model&source=bl&ots=QlHt5pe8fZ&sig=mPH4gLVvdECPF4N0agXsdwZ5sZE&hl=en&ei=3G9KS63OOoe0tgf1l9nkDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade-off%20model&f=false "Business and microeconomics: an introduction to the market economy"], Routledge, 1994, p. 175-178</ref> That is, government regulators who are faced with a proposed merger need to examine each proposal on a case by case basis. In some instances, the cost savings might make it worth the loss of competition, while in others they will not. This is in contrast to a "non-discretionary" policy where regulators set certain standards that any industry must meet - for example, that no firm has more than 20% market share. Then, they do not actually examine the potential gains or losses to consumer or producer surplus from a proposed merger, but only its impact on meeting the set standard - for example, whether or not the merger will increase a single firm's market share above 20%.<ref name=CLP/>
The model has been applied to the study of mergers in the US rail freight industry and the US food industry, among others.<ref>Ivaldi, Marc and McCullough, Gerard, [http://www.cepr.org/pubs/new-dps/dplist.asp?dpno=5000 "Welfare Trade-Offs in US Rail Mergers"], Centre for Economic Policy Research</ref><ref>Sanjib Bhuyan, [http://ageconsearch.umn.edu/bitstream/20469/1/sp01bh01.pdf "Impact of Vertical Mergers on Food Industry Profitability: An Empirical Evaluation"]</ref> It has also been used in evaluation of actual antitrust laws by American legal scholar and judge [[Robert Bork]].<ref name=Fink>Richard Fink, [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/119536139/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0 "General and partial equilibruim theory in Bork's antitrust analysis"], paper delivered at the Annual Western Economic Association International Conference, Las Vegas, Nevada, June 24–28, 1984</ref> A regulatory approach based on the model was popular in the United States in the 1980s and influenced much antitrust legislation.<ref>Patrick A McNutt, "Signalling, Strategy and Management Type" [http://www.patrickmcnutt.com/docs/Chapter%207%20Antitrust%20And%20Public%20Policy.pdf Chapter 7, Antitrust & Public Policy]</ref>
==Criticisms and limitations==
#The "trade-off" in the Williamson model involves a gain in producers' (firms') surplus and a loss in consumers' surplus. Thus, in focusing the analysis on total surplus, it neglects distributional issues and treats changes in both consumers' and producers' welfare symmetrically. However, anti-trust policy as actually practiced in many countries ([[Europe]], [[Canada]] and [[United States|US]]) appears to have the goal of maximizing consumer surplus (or this goal is stated explicitly).<ref name=Zulfi>S. Zulfi Sadeque, Competition Bureau, Industry Canada, Government of Canada, [http://www.apeccp.org.tw/doc/Workshop/w1996/doc8.htm "Some Aspects of Competition Policy: the View from Canada"], APEC Workshop on Competition Policy and Deregulation, August 17–18, 1996</ref> In that sense, as long as the post-merger market price is higher than pre-merger, the fact that producer surplus and firm profits rise is immaterial from the point of view of the regulators. In that case, only those mergers in which the fall in unit cost is sufficiently large to ensure a lower price after the merger should be permitted.<ref name=AnP>Michael Whinston in Mark Armstrong, Robert Porter, eds. [https://books.google.com/books?id=bvrn72h8dDwC&pg=PT449&lpg=PT449&dq=Williamson+trade-off+model&source=bl&ots=suaMKWbVit&sig=7NbiL-LKBviWCutjwAFTGPGD88U&hl=en&ei=3G9KS63OOoe0tgf1l9nkDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCEQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade-off%20model&f=false "Handbook of industrial organization, Volume 3"], Elsevier, 2007, p. 2373-2375</ref> For this reason, the Williamson model is not applicable in [[European Community competition law]] and is controversial in Canada.<ref name=Monti>Giorgio Monti, [https://books.google.com/books?id=hHe2PklOqPUC&pg=PT292&lpg=PT292&dq=Williamson+trade+off+model&source=bl&ots=hJXOk9GH_P&sig=P5OnAH62CPCxHSLGDN97qysclZY&hl=en&ei=FmNNS7e4KInUM-W-9fcM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CBIQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=Williamson%20trade%20off%20model&f=false "EC competition law"], Cambridge University Press, 2007, p. 292</ref> #The simplest version of the model compares a situation where initially the market is competitive to a situation where the post-merger market is not. However, if initially price exceeds marginal cost (i.e. the market is not competitive), further increases in price have a "first order" effect on consumer surplus (graphically, they are trapezoids).<ref name=AnP/> #The model is limited in that it only considers the effect of the merger on price charged by the firm(s). However, in most real life situations, firms compete on many other aspects other than price, for example product quality, capacity, research and development, and product differentiation. These variables are also likely to be affected by a merger and the basic model does not capture these effects. However, the model can and has been extended in these directions by more recent work.<ref name=AnP/> #The model ignores the possibilities that the same cost reductions and efficiency gains (once technologically feasible) may arise on their own due without any need for a merger,<ref name=Paddy>Paddy McNutt, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qZTdn1JtFV4C&cd=1e "Law, economics and antitrust: towards a new perspective"], Edward Elgar Publishing, 2005, p. 221</ref> for example via own-firm investment.

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=September 2018}} {{COI|date=September 2018}} {{peacock|date=September 2018}} {{unreliable sources|date=September 2018}} }} '''Yadin B. Kaufmann''' ({{lang-he|ידין קאופמן}}; born July 31, 1959) is an [[Israel|Israeli]]-[[United States|American]] technology investor, social entrepreneur and writer.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://gt.foreignpolicy.com/2017/profile/yadin-kaufmann?c0244ec121=|title=FP's 2017 Global Thinkers: Yadin Kaufmann|last=Dubin|first=Rhys|date=|website=FP's 2017 Global Thinkers|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref> Kaufmann has played a key role in [[Venture capital in Israel|Israel’s venture capital scene]] since the “[[Start-up Nation|Startup Nation’s]]” tech boom began in the 1980s <ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://en.globes.co.il/en/article-522693|title=Athena from 1985, and Veritas from 1990; Gideon Tolkowsky and his partner Yadin Kaufman are the “elders of the Israeli VC tribe”.|last=Bashan|first=Tsafrir|date=16 September 2001|work=Globes (English)|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4050851,00.html|title=Israeli-Palestinian duo opens West Bank VC fund|date=2011-09-04|work=Ynetnews|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/04/16/early-investors-see-promise-in-palestinian-start-ups/|title=Early Investors See Promise in Palestinian Start-Ups|last=Hamdan|first=Sara|date=16 April 2012|work=New York Times|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/yadin-kaufmann|title=Yadin Kaufmann - Founding Partner @ Veritas Venture Partners {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=70553&privcapId=989309|title=Bloomberg: Yadin Kaufmann Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref> and, more recently, has been involved in efforts to create a [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian]] tech industry.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Helping-the-Palestinians-set-up-their-own-Start-Up-Nation-538180|title=Helping the Palestinians set up their own Start-Up Nation|last=Schindler|first=Max|date=19 January 2018|work=The Jerusalem Post|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/can-startup-nation-be-an-incubator-for-palestinian-high-tech-entrepreneurs|title=Can Startup Nation be an incubator for Palestinian high-tech entrepreneurs?|last=Lieber|first=Dov|date=3 March 2017|work=The Times of Israel|access-date=1 January 2018}}</ref>
Kaufmann co-founded two [[venture capital]] firms: Veritas Venture Partners, an Israel-based fund investing in early-stage tech startups,<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /> and Sadara Ventures, the first venture capital fund to target Palestinian tech companies.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":2" /> He also founded two [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit organizations]]: Tmura, an Israeli fund that connects the high-tech community to philanthropy in Israel,<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://www.geektime.com/2014/01/09/tmura-a-model-angel-for-vcs-and-angels/|title=Tmura: A model angel for VC's and Angels|date=2014-01-09|work=Geektime|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/1.4893964|title=Ex-New Yorker's Philanthropic VC Does Good by Doing Well|date=2006-03-03|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref> and the Palestinian Internship Program, which arranges work opportunities for young Palestinian professionals at Israel-based tech and finance companies.<ref name=":10">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2014/10/20/entrepreneurship-the-way-to-peace-in-the-middle-east/#78ce39ce18b2|title=Entrepreneurship - The Way To Peace In The Middle East|last=Rudee|first=Eliana|date=20 October 2014|work=Forbes|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/jill-krasny/palestinian-internship-program-israel.html|title=The Program Pairing Israeli Startups With Palestinian Talent|date=2014-09-02|work=Inc.com|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":6" />
In 2011, Israeli financial magazine, [[TheMarker|The Marker]], named Kaufmann to its list of the 100 most influential people in the Israeli economy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cvent.com/events/gcv-israel-2018/speakers-271c5f5ae7a14fd799cc9105b3f436ba.aspx|title=GCV Israel 2018|website=Cvent|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":5" /> In 2017, ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' magazine named Kaufmann one of its “[[FP Top 100 Global Thinkers|Global Thinkers]]”, a list of "the world's pre-eminent thought leaders and public intellectuals."<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gt.foreignpolicy.com/2017|title=FP's 2017 Global Thinkers|website=FP's 2017 Global Thinkers|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":6" />
== Venture capital career ==
=== Venture Capital in Israel === In 1987, Kaufmann joined Athena Venture Partners, Israel’s first venture capital fund, just as the “Start-Up Nation” was beginning to develop.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://today.law.harvard.edu/nothing-ventured-nothing-gained/|title=Nothing Ventured, Nothing Gained - Harvard Law Today|work=Harvard Law Today|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://paw.princeton.edu/video/yadin-kaufmann-80-building-high-tech-bridges|title=Yadin Kaufmann '80: Building High-Tech Bridges|date=2016-01-21|work=Princeton Alumni Weekly|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>
In 1990, Kaufmann co-founded, with Gideon Tolkowsky, Veritas Venture Partners, an early-stage investor in Israeli technology-based companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://finder.startupnationcentral.org/investor_page/veritas-venture-partners|title=Start-Up Nation Finder - Israeli innovation network|website=Start-Up Nation Finder|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
Athena and Veritas led seed-stage (and subsequent) financing rounds in numerous Israeli companies, including [[Mercury Interactive|Mercury Interactive Corp.]] (Nasdaq: MERQ, later acquired by [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]]); [[Electronics for Imaging]] (Nasdaq: EFII), [[Gilat Satellite Networks]] (Nasdaq: GILT), [[List of acquisitions by Cisco Systems|Class Data Systems]] (acquired by [[Cisco Systems|Cisco]]), [[M-Systems]] (Nasdaq: MSYS, later acquired by [[SanDisk]]), [[Coherent, Inc.|ESC Medical Systems]] (Nasdaq: ESCMF, later acquired by Lumenis), and others.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":3" />
=== Venture Capital in the Palestinian Territories === Kaufmann has launched several initiatives aimed at helping to develop a "technology ecosystem" in the [[Palestinian territories|Palestinian Territories]]. He has asserted that his intentions for investing in the Palestinian Territories are to improve [[Economy of the State of Palestine|Palestinian economy]] and to increase the chances of [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process|peace between Israelis and Palestinians]].<ref name=":19" />
In 2008, Kaufmann partnered with Palestinian tech entrepreneur Saed Nashef and began building the first-ever venture capital fund to target Palestinian tech startups.<ref name=":19">{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxbusiness.com/features/obama-praises-palestinian-startup-scene|title=Obama Praises Palestinian Startup Scene|last=Karol|first=Gabrielle|date=2016-03-22|work=Fox Business|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":3" /> Despite the backdrop of a [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|global financial crisis]] and [[List of violent incidents in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, 2008|recurring political hostilities in the region]], Kaufmann and Nashef raised a $30 million fund from investors including the [[Soros Fund Management|Soros Economic Development Fund]], [[AOL]] founder [[Steve Case|Steve Case’s]] [[Case Foundation]], former [[eBay]] President [[Jeffrey Skoll|Jeff Skoll’s]] [[Skoll Foundation]], [[Google.org|Google Foundation]], [[Cisco Systems|Cisco]] and the [[European Investment Bank]].<ref name=":14">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-palestinians-investment-sadara/in-west-bank-a-venture-capital-fund-hunts-palestinian-tech-returns-idUSKBN1721MQ|title=In West Bank, a venture capital fund hunts Palestinian tech returns|last=Baker|first=Luke|date=31 March 2017|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/google-cisco-back-palestinian-vc-fund-2011-04-06|title=Google, Cisco back Palestinian VC fund|last=Daniel|first=Robert|date=6 April 2011|work=MarketWatch|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eib.org/en/infocentre/press/releases/all/2009/2009-269-european-investment-bank-supports-middle-east-venture-capital-fund-first-venture-capital-fund-in-palestinian-territories.htm|title=EIB supports first venture capital fund in Palestinian territories|website=www.eib.org|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Kaufmann|first=Yadin|date=|title=Start-Up Palestine: How to Spark a West Bank Tech Boom|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/israel/2017-06-13/start-palestine|journal=Foreign Affairs|volume=July/August 2017 Issue|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":15">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kerryadolan/2012/12/18/billionaire-backed-palestinian-vc-fund-sadara-invests-in-mobile-job-matching-firm-souktel/#60ac00e116f5|title=Billionaire-backed Palestinian VC Fund Sadara Invests In Mobile Job-Matching Firm Souktel|last=Dolan|first=Kerry A.|date=18 December 2012|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>
Sadara Ventures was formally launched in 2011 in Ramallah at an event including the then-[[Prime Minister of the Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian Prime Minister]] [[Salam Fayyad]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.portlandtrust.org/sites/default/files/peb/issue55_apr_2011.pdf|title=Palestinian Economic Bulletin, Issue 55 (April 2011)|last=|first=|date=|website=The Portland Trust|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5iJtRjfUgd8&feature=youtu.be|title=Excerpt of Prime Minister Fayyad speech at Sadara Ventures Launch|last=|first=|date=9 Apr 2011|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref>
Since making Palestine’s first-ever VC investment in [[Yamsafer]], an online accommodation booking platform, in 2012,<ref name=":15" /><ref name=":3" /> Sadara has invested in a total of six [[Startup company|startups]] in the Palestinian Territories.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":6" />
US President [[Barack Obama]] referred to Kaufmann’s partnership with Saed Nashef in his [[List of international presidential trips made by Barack Obama|March 2013]] speech in [[Jerusalem]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o9Tak9w60Os|title=Obama makes a reference to Sadara Ventures in Jerusalem speech|last=|first=|date=21 March 2013|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref>
== Non-profit activity ==
=== Tmura - The Israeli Public Service Venture Fund === In 2002, Kaufmann founded “Tmura - The Israeli Public Service Venture Fund.”<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":4" /> Tmura receives donations of equity from Israeli and Israel-related high-tech companies and, upon a [[liquidity event]] such as an [[Takeover|acquisition]] or [[initial public offering]], allocates the proceeds to education- and youth-related charities in Israel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.globes.co.il/en/article-1000755277|title=Tmura offers start ups a philanthropic option - Globes|website=Globes|language=he|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>
Tmura has received options donations from more than 500 companies and has raised over $16.5 million for the causes that it supports.<ref name=":8" />[http://tmura.org]
=== The Palestinian Internship Program === In 2014, Kaufmann founded the Palestinian Internship Program (PIP)[http://palinternship.com], a US-registered non-profit that arranges work experiences and other professional development activities for highly talented Palestinian graduates from the [[West Bank]] and [[East Jerusalem]] in the Israeli high-tech sector.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /><ref name=":7" />
As of early 2018, PIP has enabled 40 young Palestinian professionals to work at 25 Israel-based companies including [[Intel]], [[HP Indigo Division|HP Indigo]] and [[Thomson Reuters]], as well as a number of startups and VC funds.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.acrobat.com/a/preview/4005c2ab-7f26-4825-9d28-1a82f9ca5122|title=Palestinian Internship Program 2018 Impact Report|last=|first=|date=|website=Accessed via Palestinian Internship Program webite (www.palinternship.com)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref>
=== Breaking the Impasse === Kaufmann is a member of [[Breaking the Impasse]] (BTI), a [[World Economic Forum]] (WEF)-backed [[advocacy group]] of Palestinian and Israeli businesspeople (founded by Palestinian businessman [[Munib al-Masri]] and Israeli high-tech entrepreneur [[Yossi Vardi]]) lobbying political leaders to advance the [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process|Israeli-Palestinian peace process]].<ref name=":16">{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/.premium-israeli-palestinian-execs-call-for-2-states-1.5270032|title=Israeli, Palestinian Business Leaders Call for Two-state Solution|last=Avriel|first=Eytan|date=2013-05-27|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref><ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=https://en.globes.co.il/en/article-a-peace-agreement-can-solve-our-economic-woes-1000911966|title=A peace agreement can solve our economic woes|last=Ben-Israel|first=Adi|date=23 January 2014|website=Globes|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>
Kaufmann has spoken on behalf of BTI at high-profile WEF-sponsored events including at the group's launch event at the [[Dead Sea]], [[Jordan]] in 2013<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vgQ_89sjNb0&feature=youtu.be|title=Jordan 2013 - Press Conference Breaking the Impasse|last=|first=|date=26 May 2013|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":16" /> and at [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]] in 2014.<ref name=":17" />
== Writing and public speaking == In 1978, Kaufmann and his then-girlfriend (now wife), Lori Banov Kaufmann wrote ''Summer ’79 in France''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pBZbAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA14-PA7&lpg=RA14-PA7&dq=Summer+%E2%80%9979+in+France+kaufmann#v=onepage&q=Summer%20%E2%80%9979%20in%20France%20kaufmann&f=false|title=Princeton Alumni Weekly, Volume 79|last=|first=|date=21 May 1979|publisher=Princeton Alumni Weekly|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=7}}</ref> Kaufmann then wrote ''Boston Ice Cream Lover’s Guide'',<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Boston ice cream lover's guide: A heavenly tour of over 55 of the Hub's finest ice cream shops|last=Kaufmann|first=Yadin|publisher=Addison-Wesley|year=1985|isbn=978-0201126907|location=United States|pages=}}</ref> which was published by [[Addison-Wesley]] in 1985.<ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url=http://www.princeton.edu/paw/web_exclusives/alumni_spotlight/as_041906kaufmann.html|title=Lots of advice: Yadin Kaufmann '80 puts hundreds of heads together|last=|first=|date=19 April 2006|website=Princeton Alumni Weekly|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thewriterslife.blogspot.com/2008/08/virtual-book-tour-interview-with-mark.html|title=Virtual Book Tour: Interview with Mark Bernstein and Yadin Kaufmann|last=|first=|date=4 August 2008|website=The Writer's Life eMagazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>
In 2004, Kaufmann co-founded (with Mark Bernstein) [http://www.hundredsofheads.com Hundreds of Heads Books] to publish a series of books that help people through life’s biggest challenges, based on advice and entertaining experiences collected from hundreds of people across the US who have "been there, done that".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2004/10/29/students-advise-frosh-venture-capitalist-and/|title=Students Advise Frosh: Book for freshmen advertised in time for parent's weekend|last=Vaughn|first=Emer|date=29 October 2018|work=The Harvard Crimson|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref> Their best-selling book ''How to Survive Your Freshman Year''<ref>{{Cite book|title=How to Survive Your Freshman Year|last=Kaufmann|first=Yadin|publisher=Hundreds of Heads Books|year=2004|isbn=978-1933512617|location=United States|pages=}}</ref> is in its 5th edition.<ref name=":18" />
Kaufmann has written [[op-ed]] articles about his professional activities, especially relating to the role Israel can play in promoting Palestinian private sector technology-related enterprise. In 2017, he wrote a feature article in [[Foreign Affairs]] entitled, “Start-Up Palestine: How to Spark a West Bank Tech Boom.”<ref name=":13" /> He has also published articles in the [[The Times of Israel|Times of Israel]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.timesofisrael.com/yes-business-can-make-the-world-better|title=Getting business invested in social change|last=Kaufmann|first=Yadin|date=18 March 2014|website=Times of Israel|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref> and [[Haaretz]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/opinion/the-economic-case-for-peace-1.5254899|title=The Economic Case for Peace in the Middle East|last=Kaufmann|first=Yadin|date=7 September 2014|website=Haaretz|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref> When studying a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] at [[Harvard Law School]],<ref name=":12" /> Kaufmann was an editor of the [[Harvard Law Review]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/hlr97&div=40&id=&page=|title=Harvard Law Review (1983-1984) Editorial Board|last=|first=|date=|website=HeinOnline|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":5" />
He has spoken at forums including [[TED (conference)|TEDx]] Rome,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gQBDPm8fwLw&feature=youtu.be|title=Can business make the world a better place? by Yadin Kaufmann at TEDxRoma|last=|first=|date=11 March 2014|website=YouTube|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 August 2018}}</ref> StartupGrind Ramallah,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.startupgrind.com/events/details/startup-grind-ramallah-hosted-yadin-kaufmann-sadara-ventures|title=Yadin Kaufmann (Sadara Ventures)|website=www.startupgrind.com|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref> [[Seeds of Peace]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.seedsofpeace.org/seeds-of-peace-at-25-our-gather-symposium-and-25th-anniversary-benefit|title=Seeds of Peace at 25: Our GATHER Symposium and 25th Anniversary Benefit - Seeds of Peace|website=www.seedsofpeace.org|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref> [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee|American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC)]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.policyconference.org/gallery/speakers2018.asp|title=2018 AIPAC Conference Speakers|last=|first=|date=|website=www.policyconference.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref> and [[Digital Life Design|DLD Tel Aviv]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dld-conference.com/users/yadin-kaufmann|title=Yadin Kaufmann|website=DLD Conference|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Yuri Gurski |image = YuryGursky.jpg |alt = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|1|23}} |birth_place = [[Minsk]] |residence = [[Limassol]] |years_active = |net_worth = |title = |boards = |spouse = {{marriage||December 12, 2015}} |children = |parents = }} '''Yuri Gurski''' ({{lang-be|Юры Анатол'евіч Гурскі}}, born 23 January 1983, Minsk, BSSR, USSR) is a Belarusian IT entrepreneur, founder of a number of successful start-ups subsequently acquired by [[Facebook]], [[Mail.ru Group]], [[Google]] and Israeli billionaire [[Teddy Sagi]]. In 2016, GoalEurope named Gurski "the most successful IT entrepreneur in Eastern Europe".<ref name="goal">{{cite web|url=http://goaleurope.com/2016/07/27/want-the-mentor-of-prisma-msqrd-maps-me-invest-in-your-startup/|title=Want the mentor of Prisma, MSQRD, Maps.me invest in your startup?|author=|date=27 July 2016|website=goaleurope.com|accessdate=6 March 2018}}</ref>
== Life == Yuri Gurski was born on 23 January 1983 in [[Minsk]].<ref>[https://42.tut.by/191797 Интервью по понедельникам: Viaden Media], {{ru icon}}</ref>
In 2000, he graduated from secondary school No. 219 in Minsk. In 2008, he received a diploma in journalism from [[Belarusian State University]]. In 2010, he obtained an Executive MBA degree from the IPM Business School under the [[Kozminsky University]] program (Warsaw).<ref>[http://www.ipm.by/programms/emba/embaprocess/ Бизнес-школа ИПМ - Учебный процесс], {{ru icon}}</ref><ref name="ej">[https://ej.by/rating/business2017/yuriy-gurskiy.html Юрий Гурский в ТОП 200 успешных и влиятельных бизнесменов Беларуси - 2017], Ежедневник, {{ru icon}}</ref>
He worked as the CEO of the Piter M LLC (the representative office of the Piter publishing house in Minsk) from September 2003 to December 2009. Since 2006, he has been working in the IT sector. Co-founder and CEO of Viaden Media, CEO of Sport.com. Worked in the Mail.ru Group corporation (Russia) from November 2014 to July 29, 2016.<ref>[https://corp.mail.ru/ru/press/releases/9520/ Mail.Ru Group объявляет о новых назначениях], {{ru icon}}</ref><ref name="goal" />
He resides in the city of [[Limassol]], [[Cyprus]]. Founder of Haxus.com.<ref name="facebook">[https://www.facebook.com/yurigurski/about?sw_fnr_id=4170722674&fnr_t=0 Юрий Гурский], {{ru icon}}</ref>
Yuri Gurski got married on 12 December 2015. He speaks Russian, Belarusian, and English.<ref name="facebook" />
== IT-Business == In 2009, Gurski co-founded [[Viaden Media]].<ref name="ej" /> The company’s main focus was creation of IT solutions for online casinos and health monitoring applications.<ref>[http://www.rbc.ru/technology_and_media/11/03/2016/56e158739a79473e42093a9b Минский экспресс: зачем Facebook купил совсем молодой сервис MSQRD], РБК, {{ru icon}}</ref> In 2011, Viaden Media received the [[App Store Rewind]] award.<ref>[https://dev.by/news/43778 Компания Viaden Media получила награду App Store Rewind 2011], {{ru icon}}</ref> In 2012, Viaden Media was acquired by Israeli billionaire [[Teddy Sagi]].<ref name="naviny">[http://naviny.by/rubrics/computer/2016/02/10/ic_news_128_470602 Белорусский IT-бизнесмен Юрий Гурский стал вице-президентом Mail.Ru Group], {{ru icon}}</ref>
Under Gurski’s leadership, Sport.com developed a number of popular mobile applications for sports and fitness.<ref>[https://probusiness.io/management/165-yuriy-gurskiy-obyavil-ob-ukhode-iz-sport-com.html Юрий Гурский объявил об уходе из sport.com], {{ru icon}}</ref>
In 2014, he became a mentor of the Maps.Me project, which later that year was acquired by the [[Mail.ru Group]] corporation. Gurski also joined Mail.ru. In 2016, he held the position of vice president of new product development.<ref name="naviny" /> He left Mail.ru Group on 29 July 2016. Representatives of Mail.Ru Group stated the conflict of interests as the reason for dismissal. Gurski denies that such a conflict has ever taken place.<ref name=ej />
He was a mentor and investor of the [[MSQRD]] project (video and photo selfie app), acquired by [[Facebook]] on 9 March 2016.<ref>[https://dev.by/lenta/main/yuriy-gurskiy-ob-yasnil-prirodu-oshelomitelnogo-uspeha-msqrd «Это не чудо»: Юрий Гурский объяснил природу ошеломительного успеха MSQRD], {{ru icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-buys-popular-msqrd-face-swapping-app-2016-3|title=Facebook buys popular face swapping app for silly selfies|author=|date=|website=businessinsider.com|accessdate=6 March 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, Yuri founded Flo, an AI-powered women’s health platform.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/owhealth#section-overview|title=Flo {{!}} Crunchbase|website=Crunchbase|language=en|access-date=2018-09-02}}</ref> In October, 2018 this fast growing FemTech startup received $200 million valuation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/us-femtech-market-leader-flo-health-completes-12m-series-a-scores-200m-valuation-300729347.html|title=US FemTech Market Leader Flo Health Completes $12M Series A; Scores $200M Valuation|last=Health|first=Flo|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Google]] bought the AIMATTER start-up owned by Gurski and Yuri Melnichek.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/08/16/google-acquires-aimatter-maker-of-the-fabby-computer-vision-app/|title=Google acquires AIMatter, maker of the Fabby computer vision app|first=Ingrid|last=Lunden|date=|website=techcrunch.com|accessdate=6 March 2018}}</ref>
Yuri Gurski participated in the preparation of the decree "On the development of the digital economy" which creates unprecedented conditions for the development of the IT industry to turn Belarus into an international tech haven.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/melnichek/posts/10159747822265223?pnref=story|title=Yury Melnichek|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/vitali.valianiuk/posts/1602193789826764?pnref=story|title=Vitali Valianiuk|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/business/markets/belarus-signs-law-enabling-set-up-of-cryptocurrency-hubs-1.689806|title=Belarus signs law enabling set-up of cryptocurrency hubs|work=The National|access-date=2017-12-26|language=en}}</ref> Gurski commented on the prospects of the decree on Belarusian television.<ref>{{Citation|last=АТН новости Беларуси и мира|title=Предприниматель Юрий Гурский комментирует декрет "О развитии цифровой экономики". Главный эфир|date=2017-12-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=64uvdipZ478&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-12-26}}</ref>
== Publications == Gurski is the owner of the Ideanomix publishing house, and an author of about 30 books on information technology.<ref name="naviny" />
